text: 1. When G anaka Vaideha was sitting (to give audience), Yâ g ñ avalkya approached, and G anaka Vaideha said: 'Yâ g ñ avalkya, for what object did you come, wishing for cattle, or for subtle questions 1 ?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Yâ g ñ avalkya replied: 'For both, Your Majesty;

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 2. 'Let us hear what anybody may have told you.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: G anaka Vaideha replied: ' G itvan S ailini told me that speech (vâk) is Brahman.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Yâ g ñ avalkya said: 'As one who had (the benefit of a good) father, mother, and teacher might tell, so did Sailini 2 tell you, that speech is Brahman; for what is the use of a dumb person? But did he tell you the body (âyatana) and the resting-place (pratish th â) of that Brahman?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: G anaka Vaideha said: 'He did not tell me.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Yâ g ñ avalkya said: 'Your Majesty, this (Brahman) stands on one leg only 3 .'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: G anaka Vaideha said: 'Then tell me, Yâ g ñ avalkya.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Yâ g ñ avalkya said: 'The tongue is its body, ether its place, and one should worship it as knowledge.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: G anaka Vaideha said: 'What is the nature of that knowledge?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Yâ g ñ avalkya replied: 'Your Majesty, speech itself (is knowledge). For through speech, Your Majesty, a friend is known (to be a friend), and likewise the Ri g-Veda, Ya g ur-veda, Sâma-veda, the Atharvâṅgirasas, the Itihâsa (tradition), Purâ n a-vidyâ (knowledge of the past), the Upanishads, S lokas (verses), Sûtras (rules), Anuvyâkhyânas and Vyâkhyânas (commentaries 1 , &c.); what is sacrificed, what is poured out, what is (to be) eaten and drunk, this world and the other world, and all creatures. By speech alone, Your Majesty, Brahman is known, speech indeed, O King, is the Highest Brahman. Speech does not desert him who worships that (Brahman) with such knowledge, all creatures approach him, and having become a god, he goes to the gods.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: G anaka Vaideha said: 'I shall give you (for this) a thousand cows with a bull as big as an elephant.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Yâ g ñ avalkya said: 'My father was of opinion that one should not accept a reward without having fully instructed a pupil.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: G anaka Vaideha said: 'What is the nature of that which is dear?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Yâ g ñ avalkya replied: 'Your Majesty, life itself (is that which is dear);' because for the sake of life, Your Majesty, a man sacrifices even for him who is unworthy of sacrifice, he accepts presents from him who is not worthy to bestow presents, nay, he goes to a country, even when there is fear of being hurt 1 , for the sake of life. Life, O King, is the Highest Brahman. Life does not desert him who worships that (Brahman) with such knowledge, all creatures approach him, and having become a god, he goes to the gods.'

For space is endless. Space indeed, O King, is hearing 1 , and hearing indeed, O King, is the Highest Brahman. Hearing does not desert him who worships that (Brahman) with such knowledge, all creatures approach him, and having become a god, he goes to the gods.'
